tossups.question: When Pablo Picasso discovered this, he said, “Now I can kill myself. I have nothing else to learn.” The right side of one work in this medium depicts a ladder, while in its middle, a rope-covered deck symbolizes the separation of classes. Another work in this medium by Cartier-Bresson shows a bicycle at the bottom of a staircase, and yet another work in this medium shows a woman with her (*) hand up to her chin as two boys cry at her shoulders. In addition to The Decisive Moment and The Steerage, one work in this medium depicts a boy holding a hand grenade. Hyperrealists such as Richard Estes and Chuck Close imitated this medium. For 10 points, name this artistic medium of Migrant Madonna, whose artists included Dorothea Lange, Alfred Stieglitz, and Ansel Adams.

An internal type of this region named for Cauchy occurs when the Reissner–Nordström metric is applied to a charged type of body associated with this region. In the Kerr metric, the ergosphere touches this region at the poles of a rotating type of body associated with this region. When pair production overlaps with this boundary, blackbody (*) radiation named for Hawking occurs. In a Penrose diagram, this region is represented by a line with slope c, and an observer will never see objects enter this region, instead observing an approaching object become increasingly redshifted and slow to a halt. Light emitted from within this boundary will never escape. For 10 points, name this “point of no return” that defines the boundary of a black hole.

In one novel, this character gradually changes his mind while on a train to Paris to visit his lover Cécile. That work about this character is Michel Butor's La Modification. In a short story by Lorrie Moore, this character falls into decline despite her aspiration to become a writer. In another work, this character is directed by Mr. Cavedagna to a serial forger named (*) Ernest Marana. In that novel, this protagonist meets Ludmila and discovers that he is reading some Polish novel called Outside the Town of Malbork. This character is also the protagonist of Jay McInerney’s Bright Lights, Big City. For 10 points, name this character who is the protagonist of Italo Calvino’s If on a winter's night a traveler and other works written in the second person.
tossups.answer: you [accept answers indicating the reader or second person narration before mention] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: you [accept answers indicating the readeraccept second person narration before mention]

tossups.question: The English chemist John Mayow called an allotrope of this element spiritus nitroaereus after experiments he conducted with antimony, water, mice, and candles. This element was produced in experiments conducted by Pierre Bayen and by Robert Hooke, though they did not recognize its chemical form, instead hypothesizing that this element’s consumption was actually the release of (*) phlogiston. This element was first discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, who called it “fire air,” and this element was given its modern name from the Greek for “acid producer” by Antoine Lavoisier because he incorrectly believed all acids contain this element. For 10 points, name this element which Priestly called “dephlogisticated air,” whose diatomic form makes up 21% of the atmosphere.

During this event, the dwarf Litr is struck by Thor and burns alive. A goddess who rides a wolf and uses snakes for bridles rides in during this event, and pushes a boat so hard that “fire flew from the rollers, and all the earth trembled.” That goddess was (*) Hyrrokkin. After this event, the giantess Rindr gave birth to Vali, who matured within a day, and slew the blind god Hodr. This event occurred because Frigg got oaths from everything on Earth except for Mistletoe, and during it, Nanna died of grief and every living creature but Loki wept. For 10 points, name this event where Odin placed Draupnir on a pyre, whispered something, and then let the ship Hringhorni be pushed into the ocean.
tossups.answer: Funeral of Baldr [prompt on Death of Baldr] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: Mayor Patricia de Lille, in anticipation of this event, has urged high tariffs for those who consume more than 50 liters per day. Approximately 37,000 agricultural jobs have been lost in light of this event, which is expected to arrive in August 2018 if the annual August rains do not come. In October 2017, officials announced that the city manager may forego standard legislation to accelerate the construction of (*) desalination plants in anticipation of this event. A prolonged 2014 El Niño has led to a once-in-a-century drought that has caused, for 10 points, what public dilemma in which a South African city runs out of a certain public utility?
tossups.answer: Day Zero [or Cape Town Water Crisis or equivalents with Cape Town and running out of water] <Halza>
tossups.answer_formatted: Day Zero [or Cape Town Water Crisis or equivalents with Cape Town and running out of water]
acceptable: equivalents with Cape Town and running out of water

tossups.question: According to Cassius Dio, the beginning of this thing occurred when Commodus ascended to the throne. Other markers of the start of this process include the death of Julius Nepos and the Military Anarchy of the third century. This process continued until Romulus Augustulus was deposed by (*) Odoacer, and one writer notes that the spread of Christianity caused a loss of civic virtue that helped bring about this process. The recovery of the Balkans by Theodosius attempted to avert this process but only succeeded in delaying it. For 10 points, name this process chronicled in a 1776 work by the historian Edward Gibbon, in which a series of barbarian tribes warred against and destroyed the most powerful Empire in Europe.
tossups.answer: decline and fall of the Western Roman Empire [description acceptable] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: decline and fall of the Western Roman Empire [description acceptable]
acceptable: decline and fall of the Western Roman Empire

tossups.question: In this novel, a Russian assistant to the protagonist is called “Harlequin” because of his multicolored clothing. Another character of this work is included in the first epigraph of T.S. Eliot's The Hollow Men, which proclaims, “he dead.” Another character paints a dark portrait of his fiancé and ends a report with the line, (*) “Exterminate all the Brutes!” A boat anchored on the Thames River serves as the setting for this work, and that boat is named Nellie. Because of the natives in this novel, Chinua Achebe called its author a racist. This novel’s climax occurs as dying ivory trader Kurtz whispers the words, “The horror, the horror” to Charlie Marlow. For 10 points, name this frame story by Joseph Conrad about a voyage up the Congo.

According to a theory of this phenomenon for humans developed by Ewald Hering, X-ganglion cells process three contrasting channels and pass on information about input differences; that theory is the opponent process. The animal with the most complex system processing this phenomenon possesses mobile, independent structures which perceive sixteen degrees of freedom for this property and is called the (*) mantis shrimp. One deficiency in perception of this phenomenon in humans is the sex-linked trait known as deuteranopia. For 10 points, identify this type of qualia perceived by cone cells in the retina, of which certain individuals are said to be “blind.”
tossups.answer: color [accept word forms; accept chromaticity; prompt on vision before “For 10 points”] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: color [ accept word forms; accept chromaticity; prompt on vision before “For 10 points”]

tossups.question: In one of these places, Mynah birds are trained to call out things like, “Attention!”; that novel is about the cynical journalist Will Farnaby who finds himself in one of these places called Pala. In another one of these places, the only religion that is despised by all is (*) atheism, and gold is used to create chamber pots and to make chains used to bind criminals. Those criminals in this place make up the obligatory two slaves per household. Raphael discovered this island after leaving for Brazil, after which he spent five years observing this place’s customs and learning that its citizens have no private property. For 10 points, name this place which titles a socio-political satire by Thomas More, a crescent-shaped island whose name has come to represent an ideal society.

This empire was separated into four divisions called suyu, which were further subdivided into countless wamani. Members of the army were conscripted as a part of this empire’s compulsory mit’a system, requiring all males to partake in the military. Although the official language of this empire was (*) Quechua, many still spoke native languages like Aymara. The leaders of this empire lived in capital city of Cuzco, which was the believed cosmological center of the universe. Running messengers would chew coca leaves so they could carry quipus, this empire’s primary means of communication. For 10 points, name this New World empire conquered by Francisco Pizarro in 1533.

A function named for this mathematician and symbolized by a Greek letter generalizes a simpler function that sums reciprocals of squares from one to a given positive integer. A conjecture named for him states that all roots of the former function occur at negative even integers or at arguments with real part one-half, this mathematician’s namesake (*) “hypothesis.” This mathematician also lends his name to a branch of geometry and to a type of surface used to visualize functions of complex variables. For 10 points, name this mathematician with a namesake integral, sum, and sphere.

This painter’s work Het Pelsken is modeled after his second wife Helena Fourment emerging from the bath. Living the final years of his life at his country home, Steen, this artist painted many natural scenes, such as his Farmers Returning From The Fields. A triptych by this man, (*) The Elevation of the Cross, was commissioned by the Antwerp Church in 1614, where he lived for much of his life. This Flemish painter of The Garden of Love names an adjective that refers to his voluptuous depiction of women. For 10 points, name this Baroque painter of the Marie de' Medici Cycle.

One member of this family has a majority of his keyboard compositions contained in the Bauyn [BOW-in] manuscript; that man also pioneered the genre of the unmeasured prelude for the harpsichord. Another composer with this last name published a work of keyboard technique titled “The Art of Harpsichord Playing” in 1716, and that composer with this last name has works contained in an edition Brahms helped publish titled Pièces de clavecin. In addition to (*) Louis [loo-ee], the most famous composer with this last name employed style brisé [STEEL bree-ZAY] in his piece The Mysterious Barricades and was memorialized in a namesake tombeau by Ravel. For 10 points, identify this French Baroque family name that belongs to François le grand.

In one poem by this author, an entity that forces the landscape to listen and forces shadows to hold their breath when it comes inflicts a scarless “heavenly hurt.” This poet imagined a bee that babbles in stolid air, and a “little Bird / That kept so many warm” appears in a work in which this poet says, (*) “ ‘Hope’ is the thing with feathers -.” This poet of “There's a certain Slant of light” said that “The Stillness in the Room / Was like the Stillness in the Air -” in a poem about the “Blue - uncertain - stumbling Buzz -” of the title creature. This reclusive poet did not name any poems and employed dashes frequently into her writing. For 10 points, name this poet from Amherst who wrote “I heard a Fly buzz - when I died -” and “Because I could not stop for Death.”

Ezekiel chapter 34 prophesies against a people in Israel with this profession, since they feed and clothe themselves without worrying about others. In John 21 after Jesus asks Simon Peter if he loves him, he metaphorically imparts this profession on Peter, and in John 10, Jesus calls himself the (*) good type of this profession. An apocryphal New Testament book is named for this profession “of Hermas,” and in Psalm 23, the Lord is said to be this profession for the speaker. In the Nativity story, a host of angels appear to people with this profession living in the countryside. For 10 points, name this profession related in Latin to the term “pastor,” people who watch over flocks.

New York v. U.S. saw the first application of this in over 55 years to invalidate a legislative act. In Printz v. U.S., Scalia invalidated the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act using this as justification. A recent and notable application of this was in the Supreme Court case National Federation of Independent Business v. (*) Sebelius, in which the majority opinion used this to invalidate parts of the Affordable Care Act which supposedly coerced states into opting for Medicaid expansion. This constitutional amendment originally included the word “expressly,” but it was later omitted by Roger Sherman at the objection of James Madison. For 10 points, name this Constitutional amendment which enshrines American federalism, the last in the Bill of Rights.

The city of Sukhumi is the capital of a separatist region that borders this body of water. The Strait of Kerch connects the Sea of Azov to the northeastern region of this body of water. The city of Odessa lies on the western border of this body water, which is also bordered on its eastern banks by the (*) Caucasus Mountains. The host city of the 2014 Winter Olympics, Sochi, borders this body of water, which also surrounds the disputed peninsula of Crimea. For 10 points, name this large body of water, which is connected to the Mediterranean Sea by the Bosporus Strait.

In one experiment, this researcher found that about half of the New Yorkers he observed waiting in line would not do or say anything when someone else cut in front of them. In another study, this man along with Bickman and Berkowitz asked what would happen if a stranger stood on a busy street looking up at a building. In yet another experiment, he sent (*) letters out to random people to see how long it would take to forward them back to himself; that experiment formed the idea of “six degrees of separation.” For 10 points, name this Yale social psychologist who conducted a famous obedience experiment to examine the extents to which people would follow the command to administer increasingly powerful shocks to actors.

A 14th century king with this name was executed by his half-brother Henry of Trastamara in the Castilian Civil War. Another king with this name was the last king of Serbia and led his nation through both the First and Second Balkan Wars of the 1910s. In November 1945, another exiled king with this name was removed from the Yugoslav throne by the Communist Constituent Congress. The son of Czar (*) Alexis I, a Romanov czar with this name, embarked with the “Great Embassy” to Western Europe to learn about new technologies. That czar with this name also established Russia’s navy in the warm water ports of the Black Sea. For 10 points, name the czar with this name, known as “the Great.”
tossups.answer: Peter [or Peter of Castile or Peter the Cruel or Peter I of Serbia or Peter II of Yugoslavia or Peter Alexeyevich] <Halza>
tossups.answer_formatted: Peter [or Peter of Castile or Peter the Cruel or Peter I of Serbia or Peter II of Yugoslavia or Peter Alexeyevich]

tossups.question: The piece Phrygian Gates and its companion piece China Gates are their composer’s opus one work in this style. The Greek composer Dionysis Boukouvalas composed a piece in this style for three people at one piano titled “Fantasy on a theme by” another composer of this movement. That theme is from its composer’s piece (*) Piano Phase, which exemplifies this style’s tape music technique that Steve Reich also used in Come Out, in which two identical instances of music are played at slightly different tempi. The first piece from this movement, Terry Riley’s piece In C, sees a group of musicians play play the title note over 53 phrases. For 10 points, name this musical style exemplified by works of Philip Glass and John Adams and named for its small, repetitive units.
tossups.answer: minimalist music [prompt on John Adams before second line] <McMaken> BONUSES:
tossups.answer_formatted: minimalist music [prompt on John Adams before second line]

bonuses.leadin: While the wealthy turned their backs on the disguised Zeus and Hermes, one couple did not. For 10 points each:
answers: flood [accept descriptions indicating destruction by water]
parts: Name this Phrygian couple who realized that they were in the presence of divinity when Hermes made wine replenish with magic.
As gratitude for their treatment, Zeus and Hermes allowed Baucis and Philemon to survive this catastrophe which occurred in their town after they left without turning back.
At their request that that when one of them dies, the other would as well, Baucis and Philemon were transformed into these objects at their death.

bonuses.leadin: This character cuts Dr. Seward’s arm, and licks the blood from off the floor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who ate animals raw, culminating in him trying to feed successively larger animals to each other in hopes of gaining their life energy.
Renfield and Dr. Seward are characters in this novel. The nemesis of this novel’s titular character is Professor Abraham Van Helsing.
Three female vampires known as the weird women, are also known by this popular name. It also titles a 1960 Hammer film also about Abraham Van Helsing.

bonuses.leadin: This four-word phrase was the title of a declaration that Germany’s aggression would end. For 10 points each:
answers: “Peace for our Time” [do not accept “Peace in our time”]
Phoney War [or Drôle de guerre or Sitzkrieg] <Yoshida>
parts: Give this four word phrase that titles a speech concerning the Munich Agreement. Do not get it confused with a similar phrase used in the Book of Common Prayer and The Avengers: Age of Ultron.
“Peace for our time” was the phrase used by this British Prime Minister famous for his policy of appeasement. He led Britain through the first eight months of World War II.
The beginning of World War II was given this name by journalists. It was named because of a lack of large-scale military battles and seems like a name that would be given by Holden Caulfield.
answers_formatted: “Peace for our Time” [do not accept "“Peace in our time”"]

bonuses.leadin: A description of the structure of this thing by John Newlands four years before its full formulation is called the Law of Octaves. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this arrangement of the atomic elements by mass and into columns and rows with similar chemical properties.
This Russian chemist was the first to fully formulate the periodic table and make predictions through its trends, arranging the 56 known elements into eight groups he envisioned in a dream.

After Mendeleev’s publication, Horace Groves Deming published a new version of the periodic table with this many columns, in order to accomodate all valence electron possibilities for s, p, and d orbitals.

bonuses.leadin: You’re enjoying a pleasant car ride when all of a sudden your uncle starts telling you about the U.S. Interstate system. For 10 points each:
answers: nuclear strikes [or nuclear war or atomic bomb or similar]
parts: This legislation proposed a toll-free interstate system. Unfortunately, there was no suggested means of funding, and nothing happened for 12 years.
One justification for pursuing this expensive project was that the interstate system would serve as an escape route if this event were to occur. Description acceptable.
The interstate system was championed by this U.S. President. This five-star general served as the supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Forces in Europe during World War II.

bonuses.leadin: On this map projection, Greenland is about the same size as Africa, though Africa is about fourteen times larger by area. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this commonly-used cylindrical world map projection created by a Flemish geographer with a Latinized name, primarily used for navigational purposes.

On the Mercator projection, Alaska is about the same size as this nation which is actually about five times as large. This country contains the longest portion of the equator, and it borders all but two of the other countries in its continent.

In contrast to the Mercator projection, this German produced a namesake world map which was deemed more politically correct since it is flattened at the poles to yield equal areas throughout. Today that projection is named after James Gall and this man.

bonuses.leadin: One master helped bring this thing to its height from his experience with hexagrams from the I Ching in the Bamboo Grove and with the historian Father Jacobus in a Benedictine monastery. For 10 points each:
answers: The Glass Bead Game [or das Glasperlenspiel]
parts: Name this “kind of synthesis of human learning” whose universal symbols allowed masters like Joseph Knecht to create games starting from a Bach fugue subject and leading to “a sentence out of Leibniz or the Upanishads.”
Joseph Knecht and previous masters of the Glass Bead Game were given this Latin title, whose name blurs the distinction between its nature as a game and as a school.
The Glass Bead Game is the last full-length novel by this German author who also wrote Steppenwolf and Siddhartha.

bonuses.leadin: St. Augustine gave the most popular name for this Latin text, the only to survive in its entirety. For 10 points each:
answers: The Golden Ass [or Asinus Aureus or Metamorphoses of Apuleius]
parts: Name this novel in which Lucius tries to transform into a bird, only to be transformed into the titular animal. Give either title.
After eating a crown of roses held by a priest of this deity, Lucius is returned to human form. This is the name of the true form of the queen of heaven according to her.
An old woman in The Golden Ass tell the tale of these two lovers. This is one of the most famous sources for this tale, and includes talking towers and ants sorting grain.
answers_formatted: The Golden Ass [or Asinus Aureus or Metamorphoses of Apuleius]

bonuses.leadin: This kingdom is a paraphyletic taxon, because its stem species evolved several times independently. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kingdom of small eukaryotes, which includes amoebae and red-tide-causing dinoflagellates.
The largest protist is this stramenopile commonly known as giant kelp. Its name refers to the presence of the pigment fucoxanthin.
These other stramenopiles are best known for their bilaterally-symmetric, rigid cell walls made of silica. Their high lipid metabolism makes them an excellent candidate for biofuel sources.

bonuses.leadin: While in a hot air balloon, this character astutely notes that if they were flying over Indiana, the land would be pink—the way it is on a map. For 10 points each:
answers: Tom Sawyer Abroad [prompt on Tom Sawyer, I guess]
parts: Name this character who argues with his friend about the rights of religious leaders to take away people’s land in the name of their god, who appears in a novel named for that friend.

Huckleberry Finn, Tom Sawyer, and Jim are trapped on a hot air balloon in this novel, the third in a series centered around Huck’s friend. They make it all the way to Africa, and return rich, as usual.
Tom Sawyer Abroad is a novel by this American author.
answers_formatted: Tom Sawyer Abroad [prompt on Tom Sawyer, I guess]

bonuses.leadin: This circuit element is equivalent to a one-way check valve by the hydraulic analogy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this circuit element which, like a valve, allows current to flow in only one direction.
According to the hydraulic analogy, electric potential in a circuit is equivalent to this quantity for water in a pipe whose difference is equal to rho g delta h.

This circuit element’s water equivalent is a hydraulic accumulator, a tank with a flexible rubber diaphragm that stores energy by the stretching of the rubber sheet and that leaks out water after it has been filled from the front end.

bonuses.leadin: When this eldest son of Edward III’s [“the third’s”] dysentery became more severe, he began performing all kinds of charitable acts. For 10 points each:
answers: Edward the Black Prince [accept Edward of Woodstock]
parts: Name this man who was nicknamed because of the color of his armor.
At this 1349 naval battle, Edward’s ship was grappled by a Spanish ship and almost sank. He was rescued by Henry of Grosmont.
Edward and his brother John helped Pedro the Cruel win this decisive battle in the Castilian Civil War.

bonuses.leadin: This painting has a sign for five-cent Phillies cigars. But wait. It’s not Nighthawks. For 10 points each:
answers: The Art Institute of Chicago [prompt on AIC] <Yoshida>
parts: Name this Helnwein parody of Nighthawks featuring Marilyn Monroe, Humphrey Bogart, and James Dean.
Another Nighthawks parody is by this English graffiti artist. It depicts a drunk soccer fan after he breaks the window of the diner with a chair.
The original Nighthawks is held in this art museum. This museum is also home to Time Transfixed, The Old Guitarist, and American Gothic.

bonuses.leadin: Cicero is one of the most famous examples of these people. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the Latin term for a person who comes from a family without prior consulship, which translates as, “new man.”
This man grew tired of populist antics, and tried to prevent the rise of the novus homo by formalizing the rules for the Cursus Honorum.

One way to gain favor with the people was to throw huge parties when serving as this magistrate. There were both Curule and Plebeian varieties of this position, which comes from the Latin for “temple edifice.”

bonuses.leadin: The “tail” form of this thing results in a functional language not adding that call to the stack. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process whereby a function is applied within its own definition, useful in creating things like the Koch snowflake.
The Koch snowflake is a type of this thing, other types of which are named for Sierpinski and Mandelbrot.

The recursively-defined inductive dimension will always be less than or equal to this dimension of a fractal named for a German mathematician. For the Koch snowflake, this quantity is log-base-three of four, or about 1.26.

bonuses.leadin: This belief is expressed in the opening of the shahada with the words la ilaha illa Allah. For 10 points each:
answers: monotheism [accept descriptions about belief in one God]
money [or wealth or similar answers indicating one’s possessions] <McMaken>
parts: Name this belief known in Islam as tawhid [tou-HEED], a belief about divine unity that is also expressed in the Jewish Shema.
In addition to the shahada, this other pillar of Islam is practiced five times a day, in which a Muslim prays while facing the Kaaba in Mecca.
Sawm [SOUM], or fasting, occurs in three different forms in the Quran—abstaining from food, words, and this other thing which is given away through the pillar of zakat [za-KAH].
acceptable: descriptions about belief in one God

bonuses.leadin: This man was behind the design of many chairs such as the Tulip, Womb, and Grasshopper chairs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who also designed the main terminal at Dulles International Airport.
Contrary to popular belief, this structure is the shape of a parabola. This Saarinen-designed structure sways when it is particularly windy.
Saarinen also designed one of these structures at MIT named for Sebastian S. Kresge.

bonuses.leadin: An example of this type of music appears to the tune of “Frère Jacques” in the third movement of Mahler’s first symphony. For 10 points each:
answers: Eroica Symphony No. 3 [accept either underlined portion] <McMaken>
parts: Name this type of music that is exemplified by a namesake piano sonata by Chopin, his second in B-flat minor. It has a slow, duple meter imitating the solemn pace of a certain procession.
This composer’s Funeral March of a Marionette is perhaps best known for being the theme music to the television show Alfred Hitchcock Presents. This composer also wrote the opera Faust.
A “largely and amply developed” funeral march in the key of C minor gives the second movement of this Beethoven symphony written in the key of the march’s relative major.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about volcanoes that have erupted in the last century, for 10 points each:
parts: Mount Pinatubo, located on this country’s island of Luzon, violently erupted in 1991, killing 847 people. This country’s capital, Manila, is located about 55 miles from Mt. Pinatubo.

This frequently erupting Italian volcano most recently erupted in 2017, injuring 10 people. The borders of eleven municipalities converge at the summit of this Sicilian volcano, making this volcano the most complicated multi-point in the world.

The emergence of this volcanic island in 1963 resulted in intense scientific analysis during and after its eruption. Located south of Iceland, this island is only expected to remain above sea level for another 100 years.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher was known for writing a non-Sun-Tzu Art of War. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian thinker who may be more famous for writing the line, “it is better to be feared than loved.”
One of Machiavelli’s more famous works is this one which focuses on the first 10 books of Ab Urbe Condita. He portrayed Rome and other old civilizations as a model for the politics of his time.
In Discourses, Machiavelli discusses the difference between religion and this concept. He argues that while religion was man made, this concept existed naturally.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about mainland Asian deserts:
parts: This largest Asian desert is bordered to the north by the Altai Mountains and to the west by the Taklamakan Desert. The Chinese province of Inner Mongolia composes a large portion of this desert.

The Karakum Desert is primarily located within this Central Asian nation. Located between Uzbekistan to the north and Iran to the southwest, this nation is home to a large portion of the Amu Darya River and borders the Caspian Sea to its west.
The Thar Desert is primarily located within this largest Indian state. With capital at Jaipur, this state translate roughly to “land of kings” in its native Hindustani language.
